panels.description:
This value compares the source cluster wall time of the incoming resolved timestamp (checkpoint) versus the current wall time. This represents the lag of the data which is actionable by Replciator.

Note that if multiple instances of Replicator are present, they may have slightly different views of this lag, based on sampling rate. In all cases, they should agree within one second.
panels.title: Lag Time

panels.description: A list of monitored instances of Replicator. The instance name is taken from the Prometheus scraper and can be used to refine the dashboard views.
panels.title: Instances

panels.description: The rate of error and warning log messages.
panels.title: Errors and Warnings

panels.description:
This heatmap shows the number of HTTP requests made to Replicator and how long they took.

Slowness in the HTTP endpoints will reflect performance of the staging database in consistent modes and performance of the target database in immedate or best-effort modes.
panels.title: HTTP Latency
HTTP Latency P50, P75, P95, P99 vs Payload Rate

panels.description: This heatmap shows the distribution of incoming payload sizes. This value will be controlled by the various changefeed flush options.
panels.title: HTTP Payload Size

panels.description: This heatmap shows the number of staging database interactions and how long they took. Slowness in the staging phase should tend to focus performance investigations on the staging database.
panels.title: Stage Latency
Stage Latency P50, P75, P95, P99 vs Mutation Rate

panels.description: These gauges shown the rates at which mutations are written and help the operator understand the overall shape of the workload.
panels.title: Stage Activity

panels.description: These gauges shown the rates at which mutations are written and help the operator understand the overall shape of the workload.
panels.title: Stage Write P99

panels.description: CockroachDB changefeeds guarantee at-least-once delivery of any given mutation. It is normal to see occasional spurts of re-delivery during range splits or cluster maintenance.
panels.title: Stage Redelivery Rates

panels.description: Errors writing to the staging tables will cause push-back on the source changefeed and ultimately contribute to the source lag metric.
panels.title: Stage Error Rates

panels.description: This table shows which instance of Replicator is sweeping any given table.
panels.title: Sweepers

panels.description: The core sequencer runs a loop that looks for mutations to apply and then applies them. The time that this loop takes is a function of the number of unapplied mutations and the performance of the staging and target databases. The specific values in this graph should taken as relative to established performance; the absolute values will vary based on the size and shape of the workload being replicated.
panels.title: Sweep Latency P50, P75, P95, P99

panels.description: Merge lag will correlate with the table that is furthest behind.
panels.title: Merge Lag Time

panels.description: This graph may show cases in which excessive time is spent within the JS runtime. This would tend to point towards inefficient user code.
panels.title: Userscript execution time vs Execution rate

panels.description: This may help to identify cases in which the staging tables are slow to read from.
panels.title: Stage read P99

panels.description: The rate at which rows are being read from staging. In a steady-state condition, this should be equal to the rate at which rows are being staged.
panels.title: Stage Read Throughput

panels.description: The age of the data being consumed from staging tables. In consistent modes, the tables for any single changefeed will advance in lock-step. In BestEffort mode, tables will advance independently from one another.
panels.title: Stage Read Offsets

panels.description: This heatmap shows the number of target database interactions and how long they took. Slowness in the apply phase should tend to focus performance investigations on the target database.
panels.title: Apply Latency
Apply Latency P50, P75, P95, P99

panels.description: This may help to identify tables which are slow to upsert into, possibly indicating insufficient target performance.
panels.title: Table apply P99

panels.description: The age of the mutations being applied to the table. This provides an estimate of the staleness of the data available within the given target table.
panels.title: Table mutation age P99

panels.description: The number of mutations that were written directly to the target table in best-effort mode.
panels.title: Best Effort Direct Writes

panels.description: The number of mutations that were written to staging, instead of directly to the target table.
panels.title: Best Effort Deferred Writes

panels.description: This shows the amount of time that a process spent waiting to acquire a connection from the respective connection pool. Sustained blocking would indicate an insufficient pool size.
panels.title: Connection acquisition blocking time
Staging Pool Dial Latency P95, P99 vs New Connections
Target Pool Dial Latency P95, P99 vs New Connections

panels.description: Tasks that write to the target database may execute concurrently only if they would not modify the same row. Tasks that have overlapping row sets must be executed serially in order to guarantee data consistency.
panels.title: Task Wait Latency P50, P75, P95, P99 vs Task Rate

panels.description: Tasks that have no dependencies on other tasks will be executed immediately, otherwise they are deferred until eligible to run. A task that is executed may be retried if it discovers an ordering requirement that could not be detected during scheduling (e.g. Foreign Key constraints).
panels.title: Task Events
